Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Why do dominant individuals cooperate? Fitness consequences of cooperative courtship in a system with variable cooperative partnerships
Award.AbstractNarration: Understanding cooperation has long interested humans, but the majority of research in this field has focused on why helpers help, because to us helping is a paradox because helpers appear to be sacrificing their own reproductive opportunities to increase others' reproductive success. However, it is equally important to understand whether and how cooperation benefits the recipients of this help (dominant individuals), as cooperation results from the interaction of individuals that may have very different reasons for participating. This research investigates the causes and consequences of cooperation by dominant males, those that have an option to cooperate or not. Using variation in cooperative mating displays within a population of a neotropical bird, the White-ruffed Manakin, this project addresses three objectives: (1) quantify the costs of cooperation for dominant males, (2) quantify the reproductive consequences of cooperation for dominant males, and (3) evaluate potential mechanisms that result in indirect reproductive benefits for dominant individuals. The research will be completed by combining traditional field techniques of behavioral observations and experiments with modern genetic techniques. This research addresses a previously unexplored aspect of cooperative display behavior, and therefore represents a significant contribution to the general understanding of the costs and benefits of cooperation. The research activities include active mentorship of high school students, undergraduates, recent graduates, and graduate students. The field component of this research is conducted at Rara Avis Reserve in Costa Rica, an eco-tourism establishment that puts researchers in contact with international and US tourists on a daily basis where they explain this research and its importance. Understanding how manakin groups function cooperatively sheds light on how cooperation may have evolved and continues to function in other animal groups and in human societies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The majority of research on understanding the evolution of cooperative behaviors has focused on why helpers assist others. The helpers by definition forgo reproduction while helping others.  This introduces a clear paradox to our understanding of natural selection where the evolution and maintenance of a morphological or behavior trait should occur only when it adds the genetic offspring success (fitness) of an individual.  However, it is equally important to understand whether and how cooperation benefits the dominant recipients of this help, as cooperation results from the interaction of individuals that may have very different incentives for participation. This research investigates the fitness consequences of cooperative courtship display for dominant individuals in a species of manakins, Corapipo altera, which has variation in the frequency of cooperation by displaying males.  By addressing a previously unexplored aspect of cooperative courtship display this research represents a significant contribution to the more general understanding of the costs and benefits of cooperation.  The variation in the amount of cooperation expressed by different individuals within C. altera offers a unique opportunity to separate the fitness consequences of cooperation by comparing not only differences between individuals but also differences in success of displays by the same individual under different cooperative contexts. The research funded by this grant included three experiments that tested potential benefits of cooperation to dominant individuals.  Overall, I found that dominant individuals benefit from cooperation through increased survival or maintenance of social status, but not through greater attraction of female or annual reproductive success. I specifically tested whether the presence of subordinate helpers led to more effective detection of conspecific intruders, and I found that males at multi-male sites responded more rapidly to the playback of conspecific vocalizations, simulating possible male intruders.  Additionally, I found rapid response of males at multi-male sites to the simulated presence of a predator, suggesting that dominant individuals may increase their chances of survival because of the presence of other males. Such survival benefits could result from increased vigilance for predators or division of mortality risk during a predation attempt. However, males in cooperative partnerships did not respond more rapidly to the presence of a female, indicating that cooperation is unlikely to benefit the dominant male by increasing this key aspect of reproductive success.  I also found that cooperating males were not more closely related to each other than expected based on population averages suggesting the kin selection is not a driving factor in the evolution or maintenance of cooperation in White-ruffed Manakins. 

In each year of the project I have mentored and worked with 2-3 young investigators (most holding a BSc, 2 holding MSc degrees) while conducting field data collection.  This grant supported the training of three such assistants.  During the 2013 season the assistants were an international group representing the US, Canada, and Italy.  Many of my assistants from previous years have continued to work in the biological sciences; seven hold permanent or contract positions with agencies or universities, 4 are working on a MSc in biology and 2 are working on a PhD in biology.  I am eager to encourage other women to work in the STEM fields and 60% of my assistants have been female.
